questions.question_text: Why does FortiGate keep TCP sessions in the session table for several seconds, even after both sides (client and server) have terminated the session?

choices.D: To allow for out-of-order packets that could arrive after the FIN/ACK packets

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibits.
The exhibits show the SSL and authentication policy (Exhibit A) and the security policy (Exhibit B) for Facebook.
Exhibit A.
//IMG//

Exhibit B.
//IMG//

Users are given access to the Facebook web application. They can play video content hosted on Facebook but they are unable to leave reactions on videos or other types of posts.
Which part of the policy configuration must you change to resolve the issue?

discussion.content:
The correct Anser is: D 
The lock logo behind Facebook_like.Button indicates that SSL Deep Inspection is Required.
Alle other Application Signatures Facebook and Facebook_Video.Play does not require SSL inspection. Hence that the users can play video content. If you look up the Application Signature for Facebook_like.Button it will say "Requires SSL Deep Inspection".
D is correct. padlock = requires SSL Deep Inspection
D. The SSL inspection needs to be a deep content inspection

Selected Answer: D
The correct Anser is: D
D is the correct. Facebook_like.Button need SSL Deep Inspection.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct ..

choices.A: Add Facebook in the URL category in the security policy
choices.B: Force access to Facebook using the HTTP service
choices.C: Additional application signatures are required to add to the security policy
choices.D: The SSL inspection needs to be a deep content inspection
It can group only physical interfaces
choices.B: Can act as a Layer 2 switch as well as a Layer 3 router
choices.C: All interfaces in the software switch share the same IP address
choices.A: It can be configured only when FortiGate is operating in NAT mode

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct about a software switch on FortiGate? (Choose two.)

comments.content: For clarification, B is incorrect because the software switch ONLY acts as a layer 2 switch, it doesn't do Layer 3 routing, the FortiGate (the firewall part) does that.

discussion.content:
The correct answer: AC

A is correct: "Only supported in NAT mode"
C is correct: "The interfaces share the same IP adress and belong to the same broadcast domain.

B is incorrect: "Acts Like a traditional Layer 2 switch" 
D is incorrect: "Can group multiple physical and wireless interfaces into a single virtual switch Interface" 

Page 181 FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4_Study_Guide

Selected Answer: AC
lgggffgfggf

Selected Answer: AC
Fortigate Infrastructure 7.0 pg 178

Can group physical and wireless. 
Only works on NAT mode. 
Acts like traditional layer 3 switch. 
Interfaces share same ip and broadcast domain.

Answer: A & C
Fortigate Infrastructure 7.0 Study Guide P.186
A & C is correct. FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4 page 181

Only superadmin has access to global setting

questions.question_text: Which two statements are correct about NGFW Policy-based mode? (Choose two.)

choices.D: NGFW policy-based mode policies support only flow inspection
choices.B: NGFW policy-based mode can only be applied globally and not on individual VDOMs
choices.A: NGFW policy-based mode does not require the use of central source NAT policy
choices.C: NGFW policy-based mode supports creating applications and web filtering categories directly in a firewall policy

discussion.content: C and D are correct. Fortigate Security 6.4 page 368

comments.content: I need to lear how to type 358

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C is correct Fortigate Security 7.0 page 458
D is correct also Fortigate Security 7.0 page 458

Selected Answer: CD
The correct Anser is: C D

Selected Answer: CD
In policy-based NGFW mode, you allow applications and URL categories to be used directly in security policies, without requiring web filter or application control profiles.
In policy-based mode: Central NAT is always enabled.
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.4.1/administration-guide/978598/profile-based-ngfw-vs-policy-based-ngfw

Selected Answer: CD
C & D is correct.

C&D
A incorrect, "In policy-based mode:
 Central NAT is always enabled. If no Central SNAT policy exists, you must create one." 
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.10/cookbook/978598/profile-based-ngfw-vs-policy-based-ngfw
B is incorrect because you can have multiple vdom with multi mode

Selected Answer: CD
C& D - Fortigate Security 7.0 page 445

C& D - Fortigate Security 7.0 page 445

A & D.
Not C - Because "Apply" is not "Create"
